title: C.A. Bella Vista
text:
Club Atlético Bella Vista, usually known simply as Bella Vista is an Uruguayan <a href="association%20football">football</a> club based in <a href="Montevideo">Montevideo</a>. The club plays its home games at <a href="Estadio%20Jos%C3%A9%20Nasazzi">Estadio José Nasazzi</a>, which can hold 10,000 spectators. 
History.
Club Atlético Bella Vista was founded on 4 October 1920.
In <a href="1981%20Copa%20Libertadores">1981</a>, the club competed in the <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a>. The club played in the same group as <a href="C.A.%20Pe%C3%B1arol">Peñarol</a>, of Uruguay, and <a href="Estudiantes%20de%20M%C3%A9rida">Estudiantes de Mérida</a> and <a href="Portuguesa%20FC">Portuguesa FC</a>, of <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>. The club was eliminated in the first stage of the competition. In 1985, the club competed in the Copa Libertadores again. Bella Vista was in the same group of Peñarol, and two <a href="Chile">Chile</a>an clubs, <a href="Colo-Colo">Colo-Colo</a> and <a href="Deportes%20Magallanes">Magallanes</a>, but were again eliminated at the first stage.
In 1990, Bella Vista won the Uruguayan league, and gained the right to enter the following year's Copa Libertadores. In the following year, in 1991, the club competed in the Copa Libertadores, and was in the same group as <a href="Club%20Nacional%20de%20Football">Nacional</a>, of Uruguay, and <a href="Clube%20de%20Regatas%20do%20Flamengo">Flamengo</a> and <a href="Sport%20Club%20Corinthians%20Paulista">Corinthians</a>, of <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>. The club finished in the last place of the group. In the <a href="1993%20Copa%20Libertadores">1993 Copa Libertadores</a>, Bella Vista was in the same group as Nacional, of Uruguay, and <a href="Club%20Deportivo%20El%20Nacional">El Nacional</a> and <a href="Barcelona%20Sporting%20Club">Barcelona</a>, of <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>. After a poor campaign, the club was again eliminated in the first stage. In <a href="1999%20Copa%20Libertadores">1999</a>, the club, after an absence of six years, returned to <a href="Copa%20Libertadores%20de%20Am%C3%A9rica">Copa Libertadores</a>. Bella Vista was in a group containing Nacional, of Uruguay, <a href="Estudiantes%20de%20M%C3%A9rida">Estudiantes de Mérida</a>, of <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, and <a href="Club%20de%20F%C3%BAtbol%20Monterrey">Monterrey</a>, of <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>. The club finished in third in the first stage, and qualified to the second stage, where they defeated <a href="Club%20Deportivo%20Universidad%20Cat%C3%B3lica">Universidad Católica</a>, of Chile. However, in the quarterfinals, Bella Vista was eliminated by <a href="Deportivo%20Cali">Deportivo Cali</a>, of <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>. It was the club's best campaign ever in the Copa Libertadores.
In <a href="2000%20Copa%20Libertadores">2000</a>, Bella Vista competed again in the <a href="Copa%20Libertadores%20de%20Am%C3%A9rica">Copa Libertadores</a>, and was grouped alongside Bolivians <a href="Club%20Bol%C3%ADvar">Bolívar</a>, <a href="Clube%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Mineiro">Atlético Mineiro</a>, of Brazil, and <a href="Cobreloa">Cobreloa</a>, of Chile. The club was eliminated in the first stage of the competition.
In 2011, the club competed in the <a href="2011%20Copa%20Sudamericana">Copa Sudamericana</a> in which they were eliminated on the First Round by <a href="Club%20Deportivo%20Universidad%20Cat%C3%B3lica">Universidad Católica</a>
Jersey origin controversy.
The Bella Vista jersey represents the <a href="Flag%20of%20the%20Vatican%20City">Vatican flag</a>, half yellow and half white. This is why the club is nicknamed the "papales", the ones who follow the papal, el papado, the <a href="Vatican%20City">Vatican</a> authority.
Some versions say the origin can be different. Due to the divided fanaticism between <a href="C.A.%20Pe%C3%B1arol">Peñarol</a> and <a href="Club%20Nacional%20de%20Football">Nacional</a> of the club's former authorities, they decided the jersey to have the predominant colors of the two Uruguayan big clubs. Note that this is exactly what <a href="Arsenal%20de%20Sarand%C3%AD">Arsenal of Sarandí</a> from <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> did when designing its jersey, light blue and red, due to the authorities of the club being <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Independiente">Independiente</a> and <a href="Racing%20Club%20de%20Avellaneda">Racing of Avellaneda</a> supporters.
